title: 2021 Stock Market Outlook (Part 2)
text: The 2020 market was extremely volatile, and no one knew what to expect. But Matt maintained his bullish outlook – and was correct!

title: Painful as it was, patience paid off for investors
text: Good things came to fund investors who waited in 2020. But, what a terrifying wait it was.

title: 2020 Stocks: A year in review and look at the stock market's wild ride
text: #stocks #investing #YahooFinance Yahoo Finance's Jared Blikre looks at the stock market performance for 2020. This segment originally aired on December 31, 2020.

title: Republican-led Senate takes first step to override Trump defense veto in rare New Year's Day session
text: WASHINGTON — The Republican-led Senate on Friday joined the House in overriding President Donald Trump's veto of a $740 billion defense policy bill.

title: Wall Street readies for more stock froth amid economic pain in 2021
text: The stock market may have ended the year at record highs, but Wall Street is now in a very different place than it was this time last year. Financiers biggest concerns in January 2020 revolved around President Trump's mercurial stance on international trade and a Federal Reserve itching to raise historically low interest rates ever.

title: Economic Preview: U.S. economy could lose jobs in December for first time since the start of pandemic
text: The U.S. economy stumbled toward the finish line as 2020 ended, with the recovery from the coronavirus pandemic slowing, putting it in danger of losing jobs for the first time since the pandemic erupted last spring.

title: Senate Set To Vote To Override Trump's Veto Of $740 Billion Defense Bill As Lawmakers Make Last-Minute Plea For $2,000 Stimulus Checks
text: The vote could mark the first time Congress successfully overrides one of Trump's vetoes.

title: The Top Stocks To Buy In The New Year
text: The seasonally-strongest baskets include gold and technology. The top stocks in each major sector right now.

title: Brief Thoughts On 2021
text: In 2019 and 2020, the S&P 500 returned 31.8% and 17% for a combined 48.8% in the last two years, or an average of 24.4% per year, and if 2018's S&P 500 return of -4.5% is included, an average of 14% over three years. The non-consensus expectation for 2021 is that Emerging Markets and Non-US will do substantially better than the S&P 500 next year.

title: The Labor Market Ends The Year On A Positive Note, But The Outlook Remains Clouded
text: Initial claims for regular state unemployment insurance totaled 787,000 for the week ending December 26, down 19,000 from the previous week's upwardly revised tally of 806,000. The number of ongoing claims for state unemployment programs totaled 5.393 million for the week ending December 12, down 64,501 from the prior week.

title: The Top 5 Most Popular Investment Stories of 2020
text: Now that 2020 has drawn to a close, I'm revisiting my most popular investment posts of the year, based on views. It was a truly historic 12 months, to say the least, but I won't be covering everything that happened.

title: China's Bond Defaults
text: Between October and December 2020, three companies were involved in high-profile, unexpected bond defaults in mainland China.

title: Market Snapshot: Here's why the Georgia runoff elections for the U.S. Senate could turn into a ‘big deal' for markets
text: The looming Georgia runoff elections next Tuesday could inject volatility in a high-flying stock market that has mostly looked past politics in favor of the brighter economic outlook next year.

title: The End Of The Central Bank Super-Bubble
text: Central bank policy has lost effectiveness. China is in decline regardless of official data.

title: 21 Best Retirement Stocks for an Income-Rich 2021
text: The ideal retirement stocks will help investors generate a sizable and reliable income stream. These 21 dividend payers make the grade.

title: Billionaire 'Bond King' Jeff Gundlach said stocks will crash, predicted a weaker dollar, and questioned bitcoin in a recent interview. Here are the 10 best quotes.
text: In a RealVision interview filmed and released in early October, the billionaire "Bond King" Jeff Gundlach said stocks would crash within 18 months, predicted that the US dollar would tumble in the long run, and voiced his doubts about bitcoin. Gundlach, the founder and CEO of DoubleLine Capital, also called out Chipotle's valuation, criticized welfare, and argued that the only US equities that made sense to own right now were the largest technology stocks.

title: The 'Happy Does' Stock Market
text: What does option SKEW tell us about where we are? Everyone is looking for the same correction.

title: Why Markets Boomed in a Year of Human Misery
text: It wasn't just the Fed or the stimulus. The rise in savings among white-collar workers created a tide lifting nearly all financial assets.

title: EM Outlook: Will Nuance Make A Comeback In 2021?
text: Emerging market growth stocks have had an unprecedented run versus value over the past decade. Growth stocks have been clear beneficiaries of the two big trends in financial markets under COVID-19 - negative real rates and great economic uncertainty.

title: Investors Beware: Stay On The Right Side Of Change
text: The five innovation platforms that we believe will transform the global economy are: DNA sequencing, robotics, energy storage, artificial intelligence, and blockchain technology.

title: Tradeweb Exchange-Traded Funds Update - November 2020
text: November proved to be the second-best performing month on record for the Tradeweb European ETF marketplace, which saw total traded volume surpass EUR 48.5 billion.
